Abstract: This study examines the complex and multifaceted role of emotion in organizations, drawing on theories of affect, emotional intelligence, and social function. Emotions are recognized as a vital component of organizational behavior, influencing employee well-being, teamwork, and overall performance. Through a comprehensive review of existing literature, this research identifies key concepts and frameworks that underpin the study of emotion in organizations. Theoretical perspectives on emotional intelligence, affective states, and social functions are integrated to provide a nuanced understanding of the emotional dynamics within organizational settings. The findings highlight the significance of emotional awareness, empathy, and self-regulation in fostering a positive and productive work environment. The study contributes to the growing body of research on emotion in organizations, providing insights for practitioners and academics seeking to understand and manage emotions in the workplace.
